snippet: An avalanche that left at least 12 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.
abstract: Avalanche on Mount Everest leaves 12 people dead, and four missing, amounting to deadliest single day in mountain's history; fatal event has focused attention on Sherpas, members of ethnic group known for their skill at high-altitude climbing, who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.

byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and GRAHAM BOWLEY
byline.contributor: Ellen Barry reported from New Delhi, and Graham Bowley from Toronto. Nida Najar contributed reporting from New Delhi, and Bhadra Sharma from Katmandu, Nepal.

lead_paragraph: An avalanche that left at least 12 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the foreign teams that pay them.

headline.main: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
headline.print_headline: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
